section.heading: Physicians, physician assistants, anesthesiologist assistants and registered nurses who give instruction or provide supervision to emergency medical attendant during emergency; emergency medical attendants, physician assistants, anesthesiologist assistants and nurses who obey instruction given by physician, physician assistant, anesthesiologist assistant or nurse during emergency.

content.p: Any physician, physician assistant, anesthesiologist assistant or registered nurse who in good faith gives instruction or provides supervision to an emergency medical attendant, physician assistant, anesthesiologist assistant or registered nurse, at the scene of an emergency or while transporting an ill or injured person from the scene of an emergency, is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any act or omission, not amounting to gross negligence, in giving that instruction or providing that supervision. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An emergency medical attendant, physician assistant, anesthesiologist assistant, registered nurse or licensed practical nurse who obeys an instruction given by a physician, physician assistant, anesthesiologist assistant, registered nurse or licensed practical nurse and thereby renders emergency care, at the scene of an emergency or while transporting an ill or injured person from the scene of an emergency, is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any act or omission, not amounting to gross negligence, in rendering that emergency care. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½emergency medical attendantï¿½ means a person who is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Licensed as an attendant or certified as an emergency medical technician, advanced emergency medical technician or paramedic pursuant tochapter 450Bof NRS; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Authorized to practice as an emergency medical technician, advanced emergency medical technician or paramedic in this State under the Recognition of Emergency Medical Services Personnel Licensure Interstate Compact ratified byNRS 450B.145.

section.heading: Physicians, physician assistants, anesthesiologist assistants, nurses and dentists.

content.p: Any person licensed under the provisions ofchapter 630,632or633of NRS and any person who holds an equivalent license issued by another state, who renders emergency care or assistance, including, without limitation, emergency obstetrical care or assistance, in an emergency, gratuitously and in good faith, is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any act or omission, not amounting to gross negligence, by that person in rendering the emergency care or assistance or as a result of any failure to act, not amounting to gross negligence, to provide or arrange for further medical treatment for the injured or ill person. This section does not excuse a physician, physician assistant, anesthesiologist assistant or nurse from liability for damages resulting from that personï¿½s acts or omissions which occur in a licensed medical facility relative to any person with whom there is a preexisting relationship as a patient. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any person licensed under the provisions ofchapter 630,632or633of NRS and any person who holds an equivalent license issued by another state who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is retired or otherwise does not practice on a full-time basis; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Gratuitously and in good faith, renders medical care within the scope of that personï¿½s license to an indigent person, ï¿½is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any act or omission by that person, not amounting to gross negligence or reckless, willful or wanton conduct, in rendering that care. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any person licensed to practice medicine under the provisions ofchapter 630or633of NRS or licensed to practice dentistry under the provisions ofchapter 631of NRS who renders care or assistance to a patient for a governmental entity or a nonprofit organization is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any act or omission by that person in rendering that care or assistance if the care or assistance is rendered gratuitously, in good faith and in a manner not amounting to gross negligence or reckless, willful or wanton conduct. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½gratuitouslyï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 41.500.

section.heading: Physicians, physician assistants and nurses who render certain emergency obstetrical care; licensed medical facilities in which certain emergency obstetrical care is rendered.

content.p: Any person licensed under the provisions ofchapter 630,632or633of NRS and any person who holds an equivalent license issued by another state who renders emergency obstetrical care or assistance to a pregnant woman during labor or the delivery of the child is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any act or omission by that person in rendering that care or assistance if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The care or assistance is rendered in good faith and in a manner not amounting to gross negligence or reckless, willful or wanton conduct; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person has not previously provided prenatal or obstetrical care to the woman; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The damages are reasonably related to or primarily caused by a lack of prenatal care received by the woman. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A licensed medical facility in which such care or assistance is rendered is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any act or omission by the person in rendering that care or assistance if that person is not liable for any civil damages pursuant to subsection 1 and the actions of the medical facility relating to the rendering of that care or assistance do not amount to gross negligence or reckless, willful or wanton conduct.

section.heading: Volunteer emergency medical dispatchers and volunteer medical directors of agencies which employ emergency medical dispatchers.

content.p: In a county whose population is less than 100,000, a volunteer emergency medical dispatcher is immune from civil liability for damages sustained as a result of any act or omission by the dispatcher in the use of a medical priority dispatch system, if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The dispatcher has, in good faith, followed the protocols of such a system to establish the priority of calls for medical help or to provide preliminary instructions to a person calling for such help; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The protocols for the system have been approved by the medical director of the local emergency medical service; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The act or omission of the dispatcher does not amount to gross negligence or willful misconduct. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In a county whose population is less than 100,000, a volunteer medical director of a public or private agency, including a health facility, which employs an emergency medical dispatcher is immune from civil liability for damages sustained as a result of any act or omission by the agency if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The agency maintains a quality assurance program for that system; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The act or omission of the agency does not amount to gross negligence or willful misconduct. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Emergency medical dispatcherï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 450B.063. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Health facilityï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 439A.015.

section.heading: Behavioral health specialists who perform mobile crisis intervention services by telephone or audio-video communication.

content.p: A behavioral health specialist performing mobile crisis intervention services by telephone or audio-video communication, whether for compensation or gratuitously, is immune from any civil liability in the performance of mobile crisis intervention services if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The acts or omissions of the person are in good faith; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The acts or omissions of the person do not constitute gross negligence or willful, wanton or intentional misconduct. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Audio-video communicationï¿½ means communication by which a person is able to see, hear and communicate with another person in real time using electronic means. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Behavioral health specialistï¿½ means a psychiatrist who is licensed pursuant tochapter 630or633of NRS, a psychologist, a physician assistant or an advanced practice registered nurse who is certified to practice as a behavioral health specialist, or a person who is licensed as a clinical social worker, clinical professional counselor or marriage and family therapist. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Mobile crisis intervention servicesï¿½ means services provided under the direction of a peace officer while engaging in an emergency response to assist a person who is experiencing a behavioral health crisis by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Screening or assessing the person for safety; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Creating a safety plan. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Peace officerï¿½ means any person upon whom some or all of the powers of a peace officer are conferred pursuant toNRS 289.150to289.360, inclusive.

section.heading: Civil action brought by public agency; award of costs and attorneyï¿½s fees.

content.p: A public agency may commence an action in the name of the agency to recover the expense of an emergency response by the public agency against any person who knowingly: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Makes a false report to a public agency that a felony or misdemeanor has been committed or that an emergency exists; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Creates the false appearance that a felony or misdemeanor has been committed or that an emergency exists, and that false appearance causes a false report to be made to a public agency that a felony or misdemeanor has been committed or that an emergency exists. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A civil action may be brought pursuant to this section even if there has been no criminal conviction for the false report. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a public agency prevails in an action brought pursuant to this section, the court may award the public agency the costs of the action and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Expense of an emergency responseï¿½ includes, without limitation, the reasonable costs incurred by a public agency in making an appropriate response to or investigation of a false report, including, without limitation, the salary or wages of any person responding to or investigating a false report, the deemed wages of any volunteer of a public agency participating in the response or investigation, the costs for use or operation of any equipment and the costs for the use or expenditure of any resources, fuel or other materials. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Public agencyï¿½ means an agency, bureau, board, commission, department or division of the State of Nevada or a political subdivision of the State of Nevada that provides police, fire-fighting, rescue or emergency medical services.

section.heading: Civil action; recovery of compensatory damages or statutory damages, punitive damages, costs and attorneyï¿½s fees; conviction of crime not required; remedies not exclusive.

content.p: A person may bring a civil action for damages against any person who, without reasonable cause and because of the actual or perceived race, color, religion, national origin, physical or mental disability, sexual orientation or gender identity or expression of another person, knowingly causes a peace officer to arrive at a location to contact that other person with the intent to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Cause the person to be expelled from a place where he or she is lawfully located; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Damage the reputation or economic interests of the person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Upon prevailing in a civil action brought pursuant to this section, the person bringing the civil action may recover: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The greater of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Compensatory damages, including, without limitation, damages for emotional distress; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any punitive damages that the facts may warrant; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Costs and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees incurred in bringing the action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A civil action may be brought against a person pursuant to this section regardless of whether the person has been convicted of any crime based upon the same facts and circumstances giving rise to liability pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The remedy under this section is not exclusive and does not abrogate any other remedy available under the laws of this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½peace officerï¿½ means any person upon whom some or all of the powers of a peace officer are conferred pursuant toNRS 289.150to289.360, inclusive.

section.heading: Action brought by natural parent; recovery; liability not exclusive.

content.p: A natural parent of an adopted child who has entered into an agreement that provides for postadoptive contact pursuant toNRS 127.187may bring a civil action against a person if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person knowingly provided false information in response to a question asked by a court pursuant toNRS 127.188; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provision of false information caused the court not to incorporate the agreement that provides for postadoptive contact in the order or decree of adoption pursuant toNRS 127.188. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a person is liable to a natural parent of an adopted child pursuant to subsection 1, the natural parent may recover his or her actual damages, costs, reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and any punitive damages that the facts may warrant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The liability imposed by this section is in addition to any other liability imposed by law.

section.heading: Limitation of liability; exceptions for malicious acts if consideration is given or other duty exists.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, an owner of any estate or interest in any premises, or a lessee or an occupant of any premises, owes no duty to keep the premises safe for entry or use by others for participating in any recreational activity, or to give warning of any hazardous condition, activity or use of any structure on the premises to persons entering for those purposes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, if an owner, lessee or occupant of premises gives permission to another person to participate in recreational activities upon those premises: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The owner, lessee or occupant does not thereby extend any assurance that the premises are safe for that purpose or assume responsibility for or incur liability for any injury to person or property caused by any act of persons to whom the permission is granted. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
That person does not thereby acquire any property rights in or rights of easement to the premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Limit the liability which would otherwise exist for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Willful or malicious failure to guard, or to warn against, a dangerous condition, use, structure or activity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Injury suffered in any case where permission to participate in recreational activities was granted for a consideration other than the consideration, if any, paid to the landowner by the State or any subdivision thereof. For the purposes of this subparagraph, the price paid for a game tag sold pursuant toNRS 502.145by an owner, lessee or manager of the premises shall not be deemed consideration given for permission to hunt on the premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Injury caused by acts of persons to whom permission to participate in recreational activities was granted, to other persons as to whom the person granting permission, or the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises, owed a duty to keep the premises safe or to warn of danger. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Create a duty of care or ground of liability for injury to person or property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½recreational activityï¿½ includes, but is not limited to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Hunting, fishing or trapping; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Camping, hiking or picnicking; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Hang gliding or paragliding; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Spelunking; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Collecting rocks; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Studying nature; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Gleaning; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Recreational gardening; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Crossing over to public land or land dedicated for public use.

section.heading: Limitations on liability; exceptions; ï¿½trespasserï¿½ defined.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, an owner of any estate or interest in any premises, or a lessee or an occupant of any premises, owes no duty of care to a trespasser and is not liable to a trespasser for physical harm caused by the failure to exercise reasonable care to put the premises in a condition that is reasonably safe for the entry or use by a trespasser or to carry on activities on the premises so as not to endanger a trespasser. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An owner, lessee or occupant of premises may be subject to liability for harm to a trespasser if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The owner, lessee or occupant fails to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm to the trespasser after discovering the trespasserï¿½s presence in a place of danger on the premises; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The trespasser is a child who is injured by an artificial condition on the premises and: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The place where the condition exists is one on which the owner, lessee or occupant knows or has reason to know that a child is likely to trespass; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The condition is one that the owner, lessee or occupant knows or has reason to know and that the owner, lessee or occupant realizes or should realize involves an unreasonable risk of death or serious bodily harm to a trespassing child; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The trespassing child, because of his or her youth, does not discover the condition or realize the risk involved in the condition or coming within the area made dangerous by it; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The utility to the owner, lessee or occupant of maintaining the condition and the burden of eliminating the danger are slight as compared with the risk to the trespassing child; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The owner, lessee or occupant fails to exercise reasonable care to eliminate the danger or to otherwise protect the trespassing child from harm. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

This section does not affect any immunity from or defenses to civil liability established by specific statute or available at common law to which an owner, lessee or occupant may be entitled. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½trespasserï¿½ means any person who enters or remains upon any premises owned, leased or occupied by another person without the express or implied consent of the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises.

section.heading: Limitations on liability; exception; ï¿½public artï¿½ defined.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, a person who creates, sponsors, owns or produces public art, or who owns, leases or occupies any estate or interest in any premises where such art is displayed, is not liable for the death or injury of a person or for damage to property caused or sustained by a person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Fails to heed posted warnings or instructions concerning the public art if such warnings are posted to warn the public against any foreseeable conditions or any misuse of the public art that may pose an unreasonable risk of death or serious bodily injury. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not eliminate a personï¿½s duty to remedy or mitigate a condition that has actually caused two or more instances of serious bodily injury. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½public artï¿½: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in paragraph
, means a work of art which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is an original painting in oil, mineral, water colors, vitreous enamel, pastel or other medium, an original mosaic, drawing or sketch, an original sculpture of stone, clay, textiles, fiber, wood, metal, plastic, glass or a similar material, an original work of mixed media or a lithograph; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is displayed in a building or indoor or outdoor premises generally open to the public, whether publicly or privately owned; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is made available to be viewed by the public without charge; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Performance art; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Literary works; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A product of filmmaking or photography, including, without limitation, motion pictures; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Property that was created for a functional use other than, or in addition to, its aesthetic qualities, including, without limitation, a classic or custom-built automobile or boat, a sign that advertises a business, and custom or antique furniture, lamps, chandeliers, jewelry, mirrors, doors or windows.

section.heading: Limitations on liability; duties of a participant in an equine activity; exceptions; definitions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, a sponsor, an equine professional, a veterinarian or any other person is immune from civil liability for an injury to or the death of a participant as a result of an inherent risk of an equine activity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A participant shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Act in a safe and responsible manner when engaged in an equine activity; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Before engaging in an equine activity, know and be aware of the inherent risks of that activity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person is not immune from civil liability pursuant to this section if the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Provided to the participant defective tack or other equipment that caused the injury or death of the participant and the person knew or should have known of the defective condition of the tack or equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Provided to the participant the equine upon or around which the injury or death occurred without making reasonable efforts to determine the ability of the participant to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Control the equine based upon a representation made to the person by the participant concerning the ability of the participant to control that equine. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Owns, leases, rents or is otherwise in lawful possession and control of the property or facility where the injury or death occurred if the injury or death was the result of a dangerous latent condition that was known or should have been known to the person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Committed an act or omission that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Was in willful or wanton disregard for the safety of the participant; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Caused the injury or death of the participant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Intentionally injured or caused the death of the participant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Failed to act responsibly while conducting an equine activity or maintaining an equine. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person is not immune from civil liability pursuant to this section in an action for product liability. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Equineï¿½ means a horse, pony, mule, hinny or donkey. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Equine activityï¿½ means an activity in which an equine is ridden, driven or otherwise used. The term includes, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Shows, fairs, competitions, performances, parades, rodeos, cutting events, polo matches, steeplechases, endurance rides, trail rides or packing or hunting trips. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Lessons, training or other instructional activities. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Boarding an equine. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Riding, inspecting, evaluating or allowing the use of an equine owned by another person, regardless of whether the owner of the equine receives money or other consideration for the use of the equine. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Providing medical treatment for an equine. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Placing or measuring gear or tack on an equine. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Placing or replacing shoes on an equine. ï¿½The term does not include a race for which a license is required pursuant to the provisions ofchapter 466of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Equine professionalï¿½ means a person who, for money or other consideration: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provides to a participant lessons, training or instruction relating to an equine activity; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Rents or leases to a participant an equine or tack or other equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Inherent risk of an equine activityï¿½ means a danger or condition that is an essential part of an equine activity, including, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The propensity of an equine to behave in a manner that may result in injury or death to a person who is on or near the equine; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The unpredictable reaction of an equine to sounds, sudden movements or unfamiliar objects, persons or other animals; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A collision with another animal or object; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The failure of a participant to maintain control of an equine or to engage safely in an equine activity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Participantï¿½ means a person who engages in an equine activity, regardless of whether a fee is paid to engage in that activity. The term includes, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who assists a participant in an equine activity; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A spectator at an equine activity if the spectator is in an unauthorized area that is in the immediate area of the equine activity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Product liabilityï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 695E.090. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Sponsorï¿½ means a person who organizes or provides money or a facility for an equine activity.

section.heading: Contents and verification of complaint; motion to require plaintiff to furnish security; order; recourse of corporation or association to security.

content.p: As used in this section ï¿½corporationï¿½ includes an unincorporated association, and ï¿½board of directorsï¿½ includes the managing body of an unincorporated association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In an action brought to enforce a secondary right on the part of one or more shareholders in a corporation or association, incorporated or unincorporated, because the corporation or association refuses to enforce rights which may properly be asserted by it, the complaint must be verified by oath and must aver that the plaintiff was a shareholder at the time of the transaction of which the plaintiff complains or that the plaintiffï¿½s share thereafter devolved on the plaintiff by operation of law. The complaint must also set forth with particularity the efforts of the plaintiff to secure from the board of directors or trustees and, if necessary, from the shareholders such action as the plaintiff desires, and the reasons for the plaintiffï¿½s failure to obtain such action or the reasons for not making such effort. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In any such action, at any time within 30 days after service of summons upon the corporation or any defendant who is an officer or director of the corporation, or held such office at the time of the acts complained of, the corporation or such defendant may move the court for an order, upon notice and hearing, requiring the plaintiff to furnish security as hereinafter provided. Such motion must be based upon one or more of the following grounds: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

That there is no reasonable possibility that the prosecution of the cause of action alleged in the complaint against the moving party will benefit the corporation or its security holders. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

That the moving party, if other than the corporation, did not participate in the transaction complained of in any capacity. ï¿½The court on application of the corporation or any defendant may, for good cause shown, extend the 30-day period for an additional period or periods not exceeding 60 days. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
At the hearing upon such motion, the court shall consider such evidence, written or oral, by witnesses or affidavit, as may be material: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To the ground or grounds upon which the motion is based; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To a determination of the probable reasonable expenses, including attorneyï¿½s fees, of the corporation and the moving party which will be incurred in the defense of the action. If the court determines, after hearing the evidence adduced by the parties at the hearing, that the moving party has established a probability in support of any of the grounds upon which the motion is based, the court shall fix the nature and amount of security to be furnished by the plaintiff for reasonable expenses, including attorneyï¿½s fees, which may be incurred by the moving party and the corporation in connection with such action, including expenses which the corporation may incur by reason of any obligation which it may have to indemnify its officers or directors pursuant toNRS 78.7502or otherwise. A determination by the court that security either must or must not be furnished or must be furnished as to one or more defendants and not as to others shall not be deemed a determination of any one or more issues in the action or of the merits thereof. The corporation and the moving party have recourse to the security in such amount as the court determines upon the termination of the action. The amount of the security may thereafter from time to time be increased or decreased in the discretion of the court upon showing that the security provided has or may become inadequate or is excessive. If the court, upon any such motion, makes a determination that security must be furnished by the plaintiff as to any one or more defendants, the action must be dismissed as to such defendant or defendants, unless the security required by the court is furnished within such reasonable time as may be fixed by the court. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If any such motion is filed, no pleadings need be filed by the corporation or any other defendants, and the prosecution of the action must be stayed, until 10 days after the motion has been disposed of.

section.heading: Action may be brought against person causing pollution, impairment or destruction of air, water or other natural resources.

content.p: Any person who is a resident of this state may commence an action in any district court of this state where any violation is alleged to have occurred, to enforce compliance with any statute, regulation or ordinance for the protection of the air, water and other natural resources from pollution, impairment or destruction, if such person has first given 30 daysï¿½ written notice of the personï¿½s intention to file suit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Such action shall be brought against the person, firm, company, corporation, association, county, city or town causing such pollution, impairment or destruction. The State or political subdivision thereof responsible for enforcing such statute, regulation or ordinance shall be named as a necessary party to the action.

section.heading: Security for and apportionment of costs.

content.p: The court may order the petitioner to post a surety bond or cash in an amount not to exceed $500 to pay any cost or judgment which might be rendered adverse to the petitioner in any action brought under the provisions ofNRS 41.540to41.570, inclusive. Costs may be apportioned to the parties if the interests of justice require.

section.heading: Relief which may be granted.

content.p: The court may grant temporary or permanent equitable relief, or may enter such order as may be necessary to enforce compliance with any statute, regulation or ordinance for the protection of the air, water and other natural resources from pollution, impairment or destruction.

section.heading: Provisions supplementary to existing administrative or regulatory provisions.

content.p: The provisions ofNRS 41.540to41.570, inclusive, shall be supplementary to existing administrative and regulatory procedures provided by law.

section.heading: Action by owner of property; treble damages.

content.p: If property has been taken from its owner by larceny, robbery, burglary, embezzlement, theft or any other offense that is a crime against property and another person buys, receives, possesses or withholds the property under circumstances that make such conduct a violation of subsection 1 ofNRS 205.275, the owner of the property may bring a civil action against the person who bought, received, possessed or withheld the property and may recover treble the amount of any damage the owner has suffered, together with the ownerï¿½s costs in the action and a reasonable attorneyï¿½s fee.

section.heading: Lender not liable for defects in property acquired with borrowed money.

content.p: A lender who makes a loan of money, the proceeds of which are used or may be used by the borrower to finance the design, manufacture, construction, repair, modification or improvement of real or personal property, shall not be held liable to the borrower or to third persons for any loss or damage occasioned by any defect in the real or personal property so designed, manufactured, constructed, repaired, modified or improved or for any loss or damage resulting from the failure of the borrower to use due care in the design, manufacture, construction, repair, modification or improvement of such real or personal property, unless the loss or damage is the result of some other action or activity of the lender than the loan transaction.

section.heading: Actions by victims of fraud.

content.p: An action may be brought by any person who is a victim of consumer fraud. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½consumer fraudï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An unlawful act as defined inNRS 119.330; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An unlawful act as defined inNRS 205.2747; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An act prohibited byNRS 482.36655to482.36667, inclusive; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An act prohibited byNRS 482.351; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A deceptive trade practice as defined inNRS 598.0915to598.0925, inclusive; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation ofNRS 417.133or417.135. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the claimant is the prevailing party, the court shall award the claimant: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any damages that the claimant has sustained; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any equitable relief that the court deems appropriate; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The claimantï¿½s costs in the action and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any action brought pursuant to this section is not an action upon any contract underlying the original transaction.

section.heading: Actions against seller or manufacturer of unapproved drug for misrepresentation of its therapeutic effect.

content.p: The purchaser of a substance which has not been approved as a drug by the Food and Drug Administration but which has been licensed for manufacture in this state has a cause of action against the seller or manufacturer for any misrepresentation of its therapeutic effect made directly to the purchaser or by publication.

section.heading: Liability for issuance on nonexistent account or drawing on insufficient money; liability for use of invalid credit or debit card.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 604A.5031,604A.5061,604A.5086and604A.5094, any person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Makes, utters, draws or delivers a check or draft for the payment of money drawn upon any financial institution or other person, when that person has no account with the drawee of the instrument or has insufficient money, property or credit with the drawee to pay; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Uses a credit card or debit card to obtain money, goods, property, services or anything of value, when that person knows or should have known the credit card or debit card is no longer valid, ï¿½and who fails to pay the amount in cash to the payee, issuer or other creditor within 30 days after a demand therefor in writing is mailed to the person by certified mail, is liable to the payee, issuer or other creditor for the amount of the check, draft or extension of credit, and damages equal to three times the amount of the check, draft or extension of credit, but not less than $100 nor more than $500. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Debit cardï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 205.635; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Issuerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 205.650.

section.heading: Limitations on liability.

content.p: A sports official who officiates a sporting event at any level of competition in this State is not liable for any civil damages as a result of any unintended act or omission, not amounting to gross negligence, by the sports official in the execution of the officiating duties of the sports official within the facility in which the sporting event takes place. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Inspectorï¿½ means an inspector of the Nevada Athletic Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Sporting eventï¿½ means any contest, game or other event involving the athletic or physical skills of amateur or professional athletes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Sports officialï¿½ means any person who serves as a referee, umpire, linesman, timekeeper, inspector, judge or in a similar capacity, whether paid or unpaid.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 41.635to41.670, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 41.637and41.640have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Good faith communication in furtherance of the right to petition or the right to free speech in direct connection with an issue of public concernï¿½ defined.

content.p: Communication of information or a complaint to a Legislator, officer or employee of the Federal Government, this state or a political subdivision of this state, regarding a matter reasonably of concern to the respective governmental entity; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Written or oral statement made in direct connection with an issue under consideration by a legislative, executive or judicial body, or any other official proceeding authorized by law; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Communication made in direct connection with an issue of public interest in a place open to the public or in a public forum, ï¿½which is truthful or is made without knowledge of its falsehood.

section.heading: ï¿½Political subdivisionï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Political subdivisionï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 41.0305.

section.heading: Limitation of liability.

content.p: A person who engages in a good faith communication in furtherance of the right to petition or the right to free speech in direct connection with an issue of public concern is immune from any civil action for claims based upon the communication.

section.heading: Attorney General or chief legal officer of political subdivision may defend or provide support to person sued for engaging in right to petition or free speech in direct connection with an issue of public concern; special counsel; filing special motion to dismiss; stay of discovery; adjudication upon merits.

content.p: If an action is brought against a person based upon a good faith communication in furtherance of the right to petition or the right to free speech in direct connection with an issue of public concern: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person against whom the action is brought may file a special motion to dismiss; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Attorney General or the chief legal officer or attorney of a political subdivision of this State may defend or otherwise support the person against whom the action is brought. If the Attorney General or the chief legal officer or attorney of a political subdivision has a conflict of interest in, or is otherwise disqualified from, defending or otherwise supporting the person, the Attorney General or the chief legal officer or attorney of a political subdivision may employ special counsel to defend or otherwise support the person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A special motion to dismiss must be filed within 60 days after service of the complaint, which period may be extended by the court for good cause shown. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a special motion to dismiss is filed pursuant to subsection 2, the court shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Determine whether the moving party has established, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the claim is based upon a good faith communication in furtherance of the right to petition or the right to free speech in direct connection with an issue of public concern; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court determines that the moving party has met the burden pursuant to paragraph
, determine whether the plaintiff has demonstrated with prima facie evidence a probability of prevailing on the claim; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court determines that the plaintiff has established a probability of prevailing on the claim pursuant to paragraph
, ensure that such determination will not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be admitted into evidence at any later stage of the underlying action or subsequent proceeding; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Consider such evidence, written or oral, by witnesses or affidavits, as may be material in making a determination pursuant to paragraphs
and
; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, stay discovery pending: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The disposition of any appeal from the ruling on the motion; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Rule on the motion within 20 judicial days after the motion is served upon the plaintiff. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Upon a showing by a party that information necessary to meet or oppose the burden pursuant to paragraph

of subsection 3 is in the possession of another party or a third party and is not reasonably available without discovery, the court shall allow limited discovery for the purpose of ascertaining such information. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court dismisses the action pursuant to a special motion to dismiss filed pursuant to subsection 2, the dismissal operates as an adjudication upon the merits. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The court shall modify any deadlines pursuant to this section or any other deadlines relating to a complaint filed pursuant to this section if such modification would serve the interests of justice. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Complaintï¿½ means any action brought against a person based upon a good faith communication in furtherance of the right to petition or the right to free speech in direct connection with an issue of public concern, including, without limitation, a counterclaim or cross-claim. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Plaintiffï¿½ means any person asserting a claim, including, without limitation, a counterclaim or cross-claim.

section.heading: Legislative findings and declaration regarding plaintiffï¿½s burden of proof underNRS 41.660.

content.p: When a plaintiff must demonstrate a probability of success of prevailing on a claim pursuant toNRS 41.660, the Legislature intends that in determining whether the plaintiff ï¿½has demonstrated with prima facie evidence a probability of prevailing on the claimï¿½ the plaintiff must meet the same burden of proof that a plaintiff has been required to meet pursuant to Californiaï¿½s anti-Strategic Lawsuits Against Public Participation law as of June 8, 2015.

section.heading: Award of reasonable costs, attorneyï¿½s fees and monetary relief under certain circumstances; separate action for damages; sanctions for frivolous or vexatious special motion to dismiss; interlocutory appeal.

content.p: If the court grants a special motion to dismiss filed pursuant toNRS 41.660: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The court shall award reasonable costs and attorneyï¿½s fees to the person against whom the action was brought, except that the court shall award reasonable costs and attorneyï¿½s fees to this State or to the appropriate political subdivision of this State if the Attorney General, the chief legal officer or attorney of the political subdivision or special counsel provided the defense for the person pursuant toNRS 41.660. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may award, in addition to reasonable costs and attorneyï¿½s fees awarded pursuant to paragraph
, an amount of up to $10,000 to the person against whom the action was brought. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person against whom the action is brought may bring a separate action to recover: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Compensatory damages; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Punitive damages; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Attorneyï¿½s fees and costs of bringing the separate action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the court denies a special motion to dismiss filed pursuant toNRS 41.660and finds that the motion was frivolous or vexatious, the court shall award to the prevailing party reasonable costs and attorneyï¿½s fees incurred in responding to the motion. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to reasonable costs and attorneyï¿½s fees awarded pursuant to subsection 2, the court may award: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An amount of up to $10,000; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any such additional relief as the court deems proper to punish and deter the filing of frivolous or vexatious motions. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court denies the special motion to dismiss filed pursuant toNRS 41.660, an interlocutory appeal lies to the Supreme Court.

section.heading: Cause of action for damages resulting from criminal violation if perpetrator was motivated by certain characteristics of victim.

content.p: A person who has suffered injury as the proximate result of the willful violation of the provisions ofNRS 200.030,200.050,200.280,200.310,200.366,200.380,200.400,200.460,200.463,200.4631,200.464,200.465,200.467,200.468,200.471,200.481,200.508,200.5099,200.571,200.575,202.448,203.010,203.020,203.030,203.060,203.080,203.090,203.100,203.110,203.119,205.010to205.025, inclusive,205.060,205.067,205.075,205.0832,205.220,205.226,205.228,205.240,205.270,205.2715,205.274,205.2741,206.010,206.040,206.125,206.140,206.150,206.200,206.310,206.330,207.180,207.190,207.200,207.210or392.915by a perpetrator who was motivated by the injured personï¿½s actual or perceived race, color, religion, national origin, physical or mental disability, sexual orientation or gender identity or expression may bring an action for the recovery of his or her actual damages and any punitive damages which the facts may warrant. If the person who has suffered injury prevails in an action brought pursuant to this subsection, the court shall award the person costs and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The liability imposed by this section is in addition to any other liability imposed by law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½gender identity or expressionï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 193.0148.

section.heading: Liability for damages caused by use of controlled substance; damages; attorneyï¿½s fees and costs.

content.p: A person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Knowingly and unlawfully serves, sells or otherwise furnishes a controlled substance to another person; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Knowingly allows another person to use a controlled substance in an unlawful manner on premises or in a conveyance belonging to the person allowing the use or over which the person has control, ï¿½is liable in a civil action for any damages caused as a result of the person using the controlled substance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who prevails in an action brought pursuant to subsection 1 may recover his or her actual damages, attorneyï¿½s fees and costs and any punitive damages that the facts may warrant.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used inNRS 41.705to41.735, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 41.710to41.725, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Advertisementï¿½ defined.

content.p: Advertises for commercial purposes the availability or the quality of real property, goods or services; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is otherwise designed or intended to solicit a person to purchase real property, goods or services.

section.heading: ï¿½Electronic mailï¿½ defined.

content.p: Viewed; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Stored for retrieval at a later time; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Printed onto paper or other similar material; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Filtered or screened by a computer program that is designed or intended to filter or screen items of electronic mail.

section.heading: ï¿½Networkï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Networkï¿½ means a network comprised of one or more computers that may be accessed by a modem, electronic or optical technology, or other similar means.

section.heading: ï¿½Recipientï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Recipientï¿½ means a person who receives an item of electronic mail.

section.heading: Action for damages; exceptions; injunctive relief.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 41.735, if a person transmits or causes to be transmitted to a recipient an item of electronic mail that includes an advertisement, the person is liable to the recipient for civil damages unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The recipient has expressly consented to receive the item of electronic mail from the person; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The advertisement is readily identifiable as promotional, or contains a statement providing that it is an advertisement, and clearly and conspicuously provides: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The legal name, complete street address and electronic mail address of the person transmitting the electronic mail; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A notice that the recipient may decline to receive additional electronic mail that includes an advertisement from the person transmitting the electronic mail and the procedures for declining such electronic mail; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The abbreviation ï¿½ADVï¿½ or the word ï¿½advertisementï¿½ as the first word of the subject line of the electronic mail. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless a greater amount of damages is provided pursuant to subsection 3, if a person is liable to a recipient pursuant to subsection 1, the recipient may recover from the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actual damages or damages of $50 per item of electronic mail received, whichever is greater; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Attorneyï¿½s fees and costs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a person is liable to a recipient pursuant to subsection 1 and the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Disguised the source of the advertisement; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provided a false return address; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provided a false address for declining additional electronic mail from the person; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Obtained the electronic mail address of the recipient through a method that was not authorized by the recipient, ï¿½the recipient may recover actual damages or damages of $500 per item of electronic mail received, whichever is greater, and attorneyï¿½s fees and costs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to any other recovery that is allowed pursuant to subsection 2 or 3, the recipient may apply to the district court of the county in which the recipient resides for an order enjoining the person from transmitting to the recipient any other item of electronic mail that includes an advertisement.

section.heading: Immunity for persons who provide users with access to network; applicability to items of electronic mail obtained voluntarily.

content.p: If a person provides users with access to a network and, as part of that service, transmits items of electronic mail on behalf of those users, the person is immune from liability for civil damages pursuant toNRS 41.705to41.735, inclusive, unless the person transmits an item of electronic mail that includes an advertisement the person prepared or caused to be prepared. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions ofNRS 41.705to41.735, inclusive, do not apply to an item of electronic mail that is obtained by a recipient voluntarily. This subsection includes, but is not limited to, an item of electronic mail that is obtained by a recipient voluntarily from an electronic bulletin board.

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, if a natural person intentionally, willfully, recklessly or negligently injures or kills the pet of another natural person, the person is liable for the following: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The cost of veterinary care incurred by the owner because of the injury or death of the pet. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the pet is injured, any reduction in the market value of the pet caused by the injury. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the pet is killed, the market value of the pet and reasonable burial expenses. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs incurred by the owner in bringing an action pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Punitive damages and noneconomic damages may not be awarded in an action brought under this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In an action brought under this section, the award of damages must not exceed $5,000 for each pet. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not authorize an award of damages pursuant to subsection 1 if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A nonprofit organization, society for the prevention of cruelty to animals established pursuant toNRS 574.010or governmental entity, or an employee or agent thereof, injures or kills a pet while acting in furtherance of public health or animal welfare. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The action is based on the killing of a dog that had been or was killing or causing damage to livestock. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person reasonably believed that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The pet presented a risk to the personï¿½s safety or to the safety of another person; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The action was necessary to protect himself or herself or another person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Livestockï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 569.0085. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Ownerï¿½ means a natural person who owns, possesses, harbors, keeps or has control or custody of a pet. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Petï¿½ means any domesticated dog or cat normally maintained in or near the household of its owner.

section.heading: Liability of employer for intentional conduct of employee; limitations.

content.p: An employer is not liable for harm or injury caused by the intentional conduct of an employee if the conduct of the employee: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Was not committed in the course of the very task assigned to the employee; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Was not reasonably foreseeable under the facts and circumstances of the case considering the nature and scope of his or her employment. ï¿½For the purposes of this subsection, conduct of an employee is reasonably foreseeable if a person of ordinary intelligence and prudence could have reasonably anticipated the conduct and the probability of injury. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Nothing in this section imposes strict liability on an employer for any unforeseeable intentional act of an employee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Employeeï¿½ means any person who is employed by an employer, including, without limitation, any present or former officer or employee, immune contractor, an employee of a university school for profoundly gifted pupils described inchapter 388Cof NRS or a member of a board or commission or Legislator in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Employerï¿½ means any public or private employer in this State, including, without limitation, the State of Nevada, a university school for profoundly gifted pupils described inchapter 388Cof NRS, any agency of this State and any political subdivision of the State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Immune contractorï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it in subsection 3 ofNRS 41.0307. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Officerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it in subsection 4 ofNRS 41.0307.

section.heading: Limitations on liability of employer for damages arising from or relating to child care provided to children of employee.

content.p: Pays money directly to an employee for use by the employee to pay all or a portion of the cost of child care and the employee selects the child care facility independent of and without any input from the employer; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Provides to an employee one or more vouchers for use by the employee to pay all or a portion of the cost of child care at a child care facility licensed and in good standing pursuant tochapter 432Aof NRS; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Directs or refers an employee to a child care facility licensed and in good standing pursuant tochapter 432Aof NRS; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Negotiates a discount or other benefit for an employee at a child care facility licensed and in good standing pursuant tochapter 432Aof NRS, ï¿½the employer is immune from civil liability for damages arising from or relating to the child care provided to the children of the employee if the damages are caused by an act or omission that constitutes simple negligence.

section.heading: Limitations on liability of employer who discloses information regarding employee to prospective employer of employee; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, an employer who, at the request of an employee, discloses information regarding: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The diligence, skill or reliability with which the employee carried out the duties of the employeeï¿½s job; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An illegal or wrongful act committed by the employee, ï¿½to a prospective employer of that employee is immune from civil liability for such disclosure and its consequences. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, an employer who discloses information regarding an employee to a public safety agency pursuant toNRS 239B.020is immune from civil liability for such disclosure and its consequences. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An employer is not immune from civil liability for a disclosure made pursuant to subsection 1 orNRS 239B.020or for the consequences of a disclosure made pursuant to subsection 1 orNRS 239B.020if the employer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Acted with malice or ill will; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Deliberately disclosed misleading information; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Disclosed information in violation of a state or federal law or in violation of an agreement with the employee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Employeeï¿½ means a person who currently renders or previously rendered time and services to an employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Employerï¿½ includes an employee or agent of an employer who is authorized by the employer to disclose information regarding an employee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Public safety agencyï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 239B.020.

section.heading: Acts for which person is liable; remedies; no criminal liability for violation of section.

content.p: A person shall not intentionally obstruct: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The ingress or egress to any public or private property from any other public or private place in such a manner as not to leave a free passageway for persons and vehicles lawfully seeking to enter or leave the property via the public or private place; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any public or private roadway, including, without limitation, intersections, so as to prevent the safe passage of vehicles thereon or therethrough. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to any other remedy, a person aggrieved by a violation of subsection 1 may bring a civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction against any person who commits the violation to seek any or all of the following relief: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Declaratory and injunctive relief, including, without limitation, injunctive relief to enjoin any ongoing activity that violates any provision of subsection 1. For the purposes of injunctive relief, a person who brings an action pursuant to this subsection is entitled to a rebuttable presumption of irreparable harm. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actual damages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other legal or equitable relief that the court deems appropriate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates the provisions of this section is not subject to criminal liability.

content.p: Repealed. (See chapter 9,Statutes of Nevada 2023, at page 54.) ACTION FOR WRONGFUL CONVICTION

A person who is not currently incarcerated for any offense may bring a civil action for his or her wrongful conviction against this State in a district court seeking damages or other relief provided byNRS 41.950. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court shall award damages for wrongful conviction in accordance withNRS 41.950if the person proves by a preponderance of the evidence that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
He or she did not commit the felony for which he or she was convicted and the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Did not commit the acts that were the basis of the conviction; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Did not aid, abet or act as an accomplice or accessory to a person who committed the acts that were the basis of the conviction; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any of the following occurred: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The basis for reversing or vacating the judgment of conviction was not legal error that was unrelated to his or her innocence, and if a court ordered a new trial, the person was found not guilty at the new trial or the person was not retried and the charging document was dismissed; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person was pardoned by the State Board of Pardons Commissioners on the grounds that he or she was innocent; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The person did not commit perjury or fabricate evidence at the criminal proceeding that brought about his or her felony conviction and the person did not by his or her own conduct cause or bring about his or her felony conviction. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court, in exercising its discretion as permitted by law regarding the weight and admissibility of evidence, may, in the interest of justice, give due consideration to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The death or unavailability of a witness; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The destruction of evidence; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other factor not caused by the person or any other person acting on his or her behalf. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may appoint an attorney to aid a person in an action brought pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of subsection 2, the following do not constitute committing perjury, fabricating evidence or causing or bringing about the conviction of the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A confession or an admission later found to be false; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the judgment of conviction was reversed or vacated and the charging document dismissed, a guilty plea for a felony. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½innocenceï¿½ means that a person did not engage in: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The conduct for which he or she was convicted; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any conduct constituting a lesser included or inchoate offense of the crime for which he or she was convicted.

section.heading: Certificate of innocence: Entry; denial of entry and dismissal of action; sealing of records upon entry of certificate; confidentiality of records not sealed upon entry of certificate.

content.p: If a court finds that a person is entitled to a judgment pursuant toNRS 41.900, the court shall enter a certificate of innocence finding that the person was innocent of the felony for which the person was wrongfully convicted. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a court does not find that a person is entitled to a judgment pursuant toNRS 41.900, the action must be dismissed and the court shall not enter a certificate of innocence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon an entry of a certificate of innocence pursuant to subsection 1, the court shall order sealed all records of the conviction, except such records maintained by the parties concerning a civil action for wrongful conviction brought pursuant toNRS 41.900, which are in the custody of any agency of criminal justice or any public or private agency, company, official or other custodian of records in the State of Nevada and shall order all such records of the person returned to the file of the court where the underlying criminal action was commenced from, including, without limitation, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and all other agencies of criminal justice which maintain such records and which are reasonably known by either the person or the court to have possession of such records. Such records must be sealed regardless of whether the person has any prior criminal convictions in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The records maintained by the parties concerning a civil action for wrongful conviction pursuant to subsection 3 must remain confidential.

section.heading: Waiver of sovereign immunity; exceptions; action not subject to other requirements or limitation on damages; law relating to absolute or qualified immunity of judicial officer, prosecutor or law enforcement officer applies to action.

content.p: The State of Nevada waives its immunity from liability in any action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900and consents to have its liability determined in accordance with the same rules of law as are applied to civil actions against natural persons and corporations, except that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The State shall be exempt from the requirements ofNRS 17.117; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who has obtained a certificate of innocence pursuant toNRS 41.910shall not be entitled to prejudgment or postjudgment interest. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900is not subject to any requirement of an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.031, including, without limitation, the limitations on an award of damages described inNRS 41.035. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

All provisions of existing law relating to the absolute or qualified immunity of any judicial officer, prosecutor or law enforcement officer, including all applicable provisions of federal and state law, apply to an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900.

section.heading: Captioning of pleadings; verified statement of facts must be served upon Attorney General; proceedings held before court without jury; appeal; doctrines of res judicata and collateral estoppel do not apply to action.

content.p: All pleadings filed pursuant toNRS 41.900must be captioned, ï¿½In the matter of the wrongful conviction of [name of the person bringing the action].ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The initial complaint filed in an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900must be accompanied by a statement of facts verified by the person and served upon the Attorney General pursuant to the Nevada Rules of Civil Procedure. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
All proceedings held pursuant toNRS 41.900must be tried before a court without a jury. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A judgment issued pursuant toNRS 41.900may be appealed to an appellate court of competent jurisdiction. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The doctrines of res judicata and collateral estoppel do not apply to an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900.

section.heading: Limitation on time for commencement of action.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a person must bring an action pursuant toNRS 41.900within 2 years after: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a court ordered a new trial, the person was found not guilty at the new trial or the person was not retried and the charging document was dismissed; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person was pardoned by the State Board of Pardons Commissioners on the grounds that the person is innocent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If any of the events described in subsection 1 occurred before October 1, 2019, an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900must be commenced not later than October 1, 2021.

section.heading: Award of damages and other relief.

content.p: In an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900which results in the court entering a certificate of innocence pursuant toNRS 41.910, the court shall award the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the person was imprisoned for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Eleven to 20 years, $75,000 for each year the person was imprisoned for his or her wrongful conviction; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Twenty-one years or more, $100,000 for each year the person was imprisoned for his or her wrongful conviction; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Not less than $25,000 for each year the person was on parole or not less than $25,000 for each year the person was required to register as a sex offender, whichever period of time was greater. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to any damages awarded pursuant to subsection 1, the court may award: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees, not to exceed $25,000, unless a greater amount is authorized by a court upon a finding of good cause shown. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Subject to the limitations in subsection 6, payment for the cost of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Tuition, books and fees for the person to enroll in any course or academic program at an institution operated by the Nevada System of Higher Education commenced not later than 3 years and completed not later than 10 years after the date the award of damages is issued pursuant to subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Participation by the person in Medicare or Medicaid, if the person is eligible for Medicare or Medicaid, or a qualified health plan offered on the health insurance exchange administered by the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange which has been designated by the Exchange as a Bronze or Silver plan, if the person is not eligible for Medicare or Medicaid. The court shall not award payment pursuant to this subparagraph for any period in which the person is enrolled in an employer-based health insurance plan. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Programs for reentry into the community for the person commenced not later than 3 years and completed not later than 5 years after the date the award of damages is issued pursuant to subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Counseling services for the person commenced not later than 2 years after the date the award of damages is issued pursuant to subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Housing assistance in an amount not greater than $15,000 per year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Programs for assistance for financial literacy for the person commenced not later than 2 years and completed not later than 3 years after the date the award of damages is issued pursuant to subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reimbursement for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Restitution ordered to be paid by the person in the criminal proceeding for which he or she was wrongfully convicted; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Medical care paid for by the person while he or she was imprisoned for his or her wrongful conviction. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other relief. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any award of damages issued pursuant to subsection 1 must be rounded up to the nearest half year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A court shall not award and a person shall not receive compensation for any period of imprisonment during which the person was concurrently serving a sentence for a conviction of another offense for which the person was lawfully convicted and imprisoned. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If counseling services are awarded to the person pursuant to subsection 2, the person may select a relative to receive counseling with the person. As used in this subsection, ï¿½relativeï¿½ means a person who is related by blood, adoption, marriage or domestic partnership within the third degree of consanguinity or affinity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A court shall not award payment pursuant to paragraph
of subsection 2: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In an amount greater than $100,000 in a calendar year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a length of time that exceeds the period of time described in subsection 1 during which the person was imprisoned or on parole. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½qualified health planï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 695I.080.

If a person in an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900has previously won a monetary award against this State or against any other governmental entity in a civil action related to his or her wrongful conviction, the person is only entitled to receive any amount described inNRS 41.950, less the award obtained in the previous civil action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a person in an action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900has entered into a settlement agreement with this State or with any other governmental entity related to his or her wrongful conviction, the person is only entitled to receive any amount described inNRS 41.950, less the amount of the settlement agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person who received compensation from this State in his or her action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900, whether through an award of damages or a settlement, and who subsequently receives a civil settlement or award relating to his or her wrongful conviction shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Not later than 4 months after the date of the subsequent civil settlement or award, notify the State Board of Examiners of the subsequent civil settlement or award; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Not later than 6 months after the date of the subsequent civil settlement or award, reimburse this State for the compensation previously received, not to exceed the amount of the monetary compensation which the person receives in the subsequent civil settlement or award. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a person who received compensation from this State in his or her action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900, whether through an award of damages or a settlement, and who subsequently receives a civil settlement or award relating to his or her wrongful conviction does not notify the State Board of Examiners or reimburse this State pursuant to subsection 3, a court may order the termination of any future payment awarded pursuant to subsection 2 ofNRS 41.950. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The calculation of an award of damages or a settlement amount pursuant to this section must not include items listed in subsection 2 ofNRS 41.950, including, without limitation, attorneyï¿½s fees and the costs for bringing the action. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½governmental entityï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 363C.040.

section.heading: Submission of claim to State Board of Examiners; claim paid from Reserve for Statutory Contingency Account; payment not effective without prior approval of Board.

content.p: To recover damages or other monetary relief awarded by a court pursuant toNRS 41.950, less any adjustment pursuant toNRS 41.960, a person who was successful in his or her action brought pursuant toNRS 41.900must submit a claim to the State Board of Examiners. The claim must be for payment of the damages or other monetary relief from the Reserve for Statutory Contingency Account, upon approval by the State Board of Examiners. Payment does not become effective without the prior approval of the State Board of Examiners.
